pullRequest.body:
Add a text-based style linter that checks all unicode characters. 

- Only allow whitelisted characters, with a suggestion to add the flagged character to the whitelist
- Some characters are specified to use emoji-variant or text-variant. The linter ensures these variant-selectors only appear in the correct places and provides an auto-fix to clean them up.

---

Discussed at [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Whitelist.20for.20Unicode.3F/near/448721083)

The current proposal checks each character against a whitelist. There is also the question of what the whitelist should contain. 

A reasonable whitelist might be "all unicode currently in Mathlib" âˆª [Wikipedia/Mathematical_operators_and_symbols_in_Unicode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_operators_and_symbols_in_Unicode) âˆª [EdAyers/mathlib3/docs/unicode.md](https://github.com/EdAyers/mathlib/blob/fb5c2ffe917049959597b0a93b872e91f4004922/docs/unicode.md). Currently implemented is a subset of this list closer to what's currently present in mathlib.

- [x] depends on: #17068
- [x] depends on: #17116
- [ ] depends on: #17129 (part 1 of this PR)
- [ ] depends on: #17131 (part 2 of this PR)
- Future note: @adomasbaliuka says: "we might add something to the Mathlib 4 docs about this as well?"

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [063b3b2533](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16215/commits/063b3b2533d8befbc6f4760369b1b37d01cad945)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.TextBased | 3 | 16 | +13 (+433.33%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 4226 files with changed transitive imports taking up over 178601 characters: this is too many to display!
You can run `scripts/import_trans_difference.sh all` locally to see the whole output.

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ASCII.allowed`
`+ ASCII.allowedWhitespace`
`+ ASCII.printable`
`+ UnicodeVariant.emoji`
`+ UnicodeVariant.text`
`+ emojis`
`+ findBadUnicode`
`+ findBadUnicodeAux`
`+ isAllowedCharacter`
`+ nonEmojis`
`+ othersInMathlib`
`+ printCodepointHex`
`+ removeQuotations`
`+ unicodeLinter`
`+ withVSCodeAbbrev`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
Would you like to take a look at the "spaces" the linter flags? (I haven't checked what this is about exactly; just looking at it in the text editor is probably not useful...)

> Would you like to take a look at the "spaces" the linter flags? (I haven't checked what this is about exactly; just looking at it in the text editor is probably not useful...)

That seems to be

 'â€¯': Unicode U+202F (category Zs: Separator, space)

I think we'll remove them from Mathlib but let's see...

I have removed all non-breaking spaces (U+00a0) from Mathlib. This might be excessive:
- I can PR it separately if the change is too big or off topic in this PR
- We may decide to *allow* non-breaking spaces

Thank you! I think splitting the removal of non-breaking spaces into a separate PR (do you know git cherry-pick?) makes sense, and would be happy to nominate it for the maintainers to look. Reading the zulip discussion, changing the spaces does not appear controversial to me.

Update: for me, splitting the space changes is positive anyway, as it's a large enough change (200 lines), completely mechanic and very different from the rest of this PR. That would be true regardless of whether the change is controversial.

I split up the whitelist strings into `Array Char` because this way it's more clear what the individual characters are.

I also removed some more weird characters (invisible, or ones that my VSCode font does not support). We can add them back if needed once most of the non-breaking whitespace is gone...

@adomasbaliuka I've pushed my suggestions from #16368 here, feel free to take it from here and make changes as you see fit!

I left the lint errors unfixed so you have a chance to look at them, I figured it's only worth fixing them once your happy with the linter

@joneugster Thanks a lot! 

After fiddling around with it for a while, I now completely changed the way it's implemented (but I think it should do the same thing as your version, except about the ' characters where I didn't understand the idea and left a comment above). If you object to this way of doing it, we can always go back, of course.

The whitelist is now only used to ignore characters. Special cases such as variant selectors and emojis are checked further and then allowed (if used correctly) **despite not being in the whitelist**. This way we have only one lookup in the whitelist for each whitelisted character, which should be faster. Speed is probably not relevant (my version, on my laptop takes 9sec, yours 14sec, not counting compile time)  but I hope this code is clearer.

There may be an issue with the usage of the `next` and `prev` functions. They operate on UTF8 bytes and give unspecified results if given an invalid position (which I'm not sure can happen with the current code but I think yes?!).

I'm also not sure about which characters exactly should have which selectors if any. Some arrows in Mathlib have text selectors, for example. For several characters in the emoji-list, the selectors don't seem to be doing anything (though this depends on the font you use). Can we check this once more?

edit: I guess I was dumb and actually the `next` / `prev` is not an issue because the positions given by `findAll` will be valid. I fixed the case where it's going beyond the `endPos`.
@joneugster LGTM

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#17068~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#17116~~
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#17129
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#17131
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Some quick comments. Overall, this linter
- flags interesting things
- does not seem to turn up something worrying,
both of which is great.

Some quick comments. Overall, this linter
- flags interesting things
- does not seem to turn up something worrying,
both of which is great.

```suggestion
      s!"unicode character '{c}' is not recommended. Consider adding it to the whitelist."

You can just make one up, perhaps "ERR_UNICODE".

Can you also update the logic for `parse?_errorContext` below, please? (You can follow how e.g. the `ERR_AUT` code is treated.)

I did it but not sure if the result is correct. Tried to add a clarifying comment and a test using #guard.
Are these things also tested in `test`? Wasn't able to find anything so far
I put the "test" I made for this `parse?_errorContext` into ` test/LintStyle.lean`.

Does this fix it? A /- Comment -/ is just a multi-line comment in Lean, a /-- Comment -/ is a documentation comment.
```suggestion
/-- Hashable instance for use with the unicodeLinter -/
Yes, ordering this would be great. I presume this contains numbers, all ASCII letters, space etc., but it's very hard for me to check (short of using the search function ~60 times).

Here's a small Lean trick, just so you know.
You can also use \centerdot to write this more compactly as `badChars.toArray.map (StyleError.newUnicode Â·, lineNumber)`; same for the definition of `badChars` three lines higher.
Can you sort the imports alphabetically, if possible? Thanks!

I didn't know where to put these, so I put them here for now.

I'll make a PR to Lean core to modify `String.get` now, so hopefully `getâ‚‚` isn't required by the time this is up for review.
(we dont actually need this to be changed in core. Replaced the one remaining occurence with `s.get? _ |>.getD '\uFFFD')`
What is the logic here? What do the ' characters signify?
outdated now. This was just a hack to allow writing the characters as `'âœ…'` but now they are written as `'\u2705'` which is much better.
This stuff is duplicated now
I believe this is fixed
This is the only occurence of `String.next`. @adomasbaliuka I guess this is fine, isn't it?
Seems fine, assuming the function is never called with an invalid position. Maybe put that in the docstring? (we inherit the fact that the result is "unspecified" for invalid `pos`)
I did it.

I think it's fine to remain conservative with the non-emoji characters, and even leave it empty for now.

And regarding your question further up, I think it's fine if you add whatever whitelist you like best to the `othersInMathlib`. Although, it's also desirable that this list here eventually decreases in size in favour of adding VSCode abbreviations for the characters.

Leaving the non-emojis empty is fine for me.

I don't understand the other point, sorry. Add what whitelist to what?

Sorry, my point was: add as many characters as you want.

(because you did have a question suggesting to whitelist even more characters already now; which you can do if you want!)

And on a completely separate issue, anything used in mathlib should probably get an abbreviation in the long run, but thats separate PR to the extension.

You mean AND, not OR?! U+0000 is not printable.

Where does the 21 come from? I think you mean `0x21` (exclamation mark).
ofc thanks for spottingðŸ¤¦ðŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ðŸ¤¦ðŸ»â€â™‚ï¸
I would call this e.g. `allowedWhitespace` so as to avoid confusion with the concept "all ASCII whitespace".
I renamed it.

I think the idea here is to parse back the text representation of the linter error into an `ErrorContext` object. I don't actually know what it's used for (seems like it's part of the code that allows adding case-by-case exceptions for the linter. Haven't tested it.). If I understand it correctly, it should be the inverse of `outputMessage`, which actually isn't strictly possible the way that we print the error (we ignore the second character, for example). 

Probably this doesn't matter and we just "best-effort" parse the error message.  I could do it if you like...
Did this.
I believe with the way this linter is called, the final \n is not part of the "line" we process.
I removed the comment and kept the check. Please double-check if you agree.
Maybe we should add some more here? Intersection of `emojis` and `nonEmojis` for example?
I added some.
I think these are genuinely intended to be non-breaking; the right solution is to put this in a code block.

Sorry these are about the text-variant-selector of the arrows characters, i.e. there were invisible `\uFE0E` following the diagonal arrows to prevent them form being displayed as emojis.

There are no spaces changed here.

If they are supposed to have the variant-selector (which is a fair choice) then, they can be added to the list of text-symbols defined here and the variant-selectors will be fixed automatically by `lake exe lint-style --fix`
These are also intended to be non-breaking; I think using the unicode escape would be appropriate here.
same here, there is no space change, but the magnifying glass received a emoji-variant-selector because its specified in the list of emojis.

For context, there are currently no non-breaking spaces in any parts of mathlib except in docstrings about condensed mathematics & cat. theory because Dagur's IDE automatically adds them after each closing \`

And the dependency PRs fixing whitespace are mainly because Dagur's quite busy and commiting a lot :D
Let's do this with Lean!
This is really quite long; can it go in its own file?
absolutely! I'll move it to `Mathlib/Tactic/Linter/Unicode.lean`

**[lint-style (comment with "bot fix style" to have the bot commit all style suggestions)]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion 'â‚ƒ', 'â‚„', 'â‚…', 'â‚†', 'â‚‡', 'â‚ˆ', 'â‚‰', 'â‚€', 'â† ', 'Ã˜', 'â…‹', ```

pullRequest.title: feat(Tactic/Linter): lint unwanted unicode

I also removed some more weird characters (invisible, or ones that my VSCode font does not support). We can add them back if needed once most of the non-breaking whitespace is gone...

After fiddling around with it for a while, I now completely changed the way it's implemented (but I think it should do the same thing as your version, except about the ' characters where I didn't understand the idea and left a comment above).
